prod_name: Lifeline Jungle Gym Suspension Trainer
title: best ever
review: great kit

prod_name: Lifeline Jungle Gym Suspension Trainer
title: Great for the price overall
review: I bought this instead of the TRX which I use at our gym when it is available.  I didn't really want to pay the higher price for the TRX and also saw some positive reviews here and there for this.  Like most things, there are some pluses and minuses with this.On the plus side is the ability to spread the straps wide on the bar for different attack angles.  The handles are comfortable and the solid U shaped section makes getting your feet in and out a lot easier.  Like the TRX, adjustments of length are quick.  It does all the same functions as the TRX so the workout is equal.On the minus are first, the straps have no identifying markings to set the length to so it isn't always exactly the same.  If you're not anal, simply moving your body off to one side or the other just slightly evens out things as far as your hand position.  It's not exactly rocket science to get it close so that you're not directly under one and the other is at a 45 to you.  But since I like convenience, I laid them on the garage floor fully extended and used a template to spray paint small dots every foot and that works perfect and wasn't hard to do.  The second was that unlike the TRX that has a nice little looped thing to slide along and hold the excess strap not needed for tension, this does not have a nice system of what to do with the excess strap from dangling.  It really isn't horrible as far as in the way when it dangles.  The rubbery slide clips they give you don't work well at all and make it worse.  I just bought 2 little plastic clip-on clamps (the black ones with red rubber clip you squeeze together with your finger tips) and after I adjust the length, I just clip it up as high as I can to hold the excess and all is well.But considering I paid about 40% the price of a TRX, I consider this a better overall system that works great in my basement.  I love the quick, simple, and yet effective workout I can do with it.  It is a nice supplement to rest of my strength training with minimal equipment required.  Just move the feet positioning and change the resistance.  The wall chart is crappy, but there's a ton of online videos that are excellent.

prod_name: Lifeline Jungle Gym Suspension Trainer
title: useful
review: Very useful.Does not replace the gym, but very useful for a home workout.Solid and well made. I prefer this one to the brand that they have at the gym
date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 29 October 2019

prod_name: Lifeline Jungle Gym Suspension Trainer
title: Love using my personal trainer’s and wanted one of my own
review: Use this at my personal trainer’s studio and just HAD to buy one for my home workout space! Love it!  Appreciate that you can move the straps close together or to shoulder width apart or further to vary the exercises even more!
date: Reviewed in the United States on 14 April 2014

prod_name: Lifeline Jungle Gym Suspension Trainer
title: Very versatile, great core workout
review: I went back and forth deciding between a TRX and the Jungle Gym, and the reviews/ratings on Amazon and other sites pointed pretty directly at Jungle Gym.  The independent mounting of each strap allows for multiple positions, and since I mounted mine on a pull up bar, keeps them out of the way.  Adjustment clips are very secure and easy to match lengths on each strap.  I didn't rate durability as I have only been using them for 2 months but they seem to be pretty bulletproof.  I am most happy though, with the core workout while working muscle groups.  Push ups in the handles or lunges with a foot in the strap is an eye opener on how much work 'Body weight only' exercises can be.  Do yourself a favor and buy this, even as just an addition to your other tools.

prod_name: Lifeline Jungle Gym Suspension Trainer
title: Awesome...Better than TRX
review: I was looking for a less expensive option to TRX. I was a little apprehensive but I am very happy I went for this one. Its not only cheaper but I like it much more. It is extremely well made, easier to adjust than TRX and more versatile. They can easily set up in just about any doorway, chin up bar, playground equipment or just about anywhere. The foot straps are great and easy to use because they stay open.  I'm 275 lbs and this will support my full weight on a single strap.the only con:The only minor thing I dont like is while using the connector piece to use the 2 straps as one, to throw over a tree branch or soemthing similar. While doing this you cant pull on individual straps. They need to both be used at the same time. Something can definitely be rigged up to make it work but it doesn't come with anything, this can be done with TRX, but overall this system is more versatile and easier to use.If you've never done suspension training its a great supplement to your routine or a good workout you can bring anywhere. I usually workout at a gym but I still use these regularly. They are also a must while traveling

prod_name: Lifeline Jungle Gym Suspension Trainer
title: Jungle Gym XT
review: I tried using the TRX system at a gym, loved the concept and wanted to get one for my home gym. The TRX system cost was double of the Jungle Gym, and not as flexible either. I can use it as the TRX is used, one attachment point, or I can open it up wide to hit muscles differently. Just as easy to adjust, all the same exercises and more. Great product
date: Reviewed in the United States on 7 February 2021

prod_name: Lifeline Jungle Gym Suspension Trainer
title: Be careful if trying full suspension - easy to accidentally unfasten
review: Cable slipped through the clasp on first use. This is because the cable release lever is easy to accidentally press if you’re in a dip position / have the cable close to an adjacent object like your arm or a wall. IMO the lever should be much more recessed to avoid this.
date: Reviewed in the United States on 13 September 2013

prod_name: Lifeline Jungle Gym Suspension Trainer
title: Your door will be okay
review: It's somewhat surprising that something so simple can cost more than $100, but the quality of the product is high. This is a fun way to get exercise, if you like dangling and swinging around a bit like me. I do not use any kind of wall anchor or free-standing apparatus, I simply anchor this to the top of the door as advertised. I was skeptical, thinking that I would hear something cracking and have to have a long awkward conversation with my landlord about what I was doing with the door. Thankfully, everything is fine. It's quite surprising, actually. Using these for 45 degree pullups is my favorite movement, and adjusting the length is so fast that it's almost instant. The buckle mechanism is fantastic. If this looks like something you would use, I would recommend it. No wall-mounting or anything fancy required. Just a door that opens away from you.

prod_name: Lifeline Jungle Gym Suspension Trainer
title: Can't Go Wrong with the Lifeline Jungle GYM XT
review: This is a great product.  I've used the TRX system, and prefer the Lifeline Jungle Gym XT.  It is more versatile since the straps aren't connected.  It is also easier to slip your feet into the foot cradles.  The straps also feel more solid on the Jungle GYM system, and the inline adjustment buckles are easier to use than the TRX system.  I used this while on vacation in Waikiki, I found some pull up bars at Fort Derussy that I attached Jungle Gym XT to, and ran through various exercises.  Prior to my vacation, I tried the Jungle Gym XT using a room door, and the entry door to the garage.  The system and door help up very well.  I was initially skeptical that you could use this system on the lighter doors  they use for bedroom, but it held up very well. To get the most of your Jungle Gym XT, I would recommend a pull up bar mount, or ceiling mount when using these.  Some of the exercises work better if you are right under the straps, also gives you additional resistance.  For the price, and the versatility, you are better off with this system than the TRX system.
date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 3 February 2021

prod_name: Lifeline Jungle Gym Suspension Trainer
title: Please remake this with more versatile, rotating handles.. Update: simple mod can fix the rotating issue, but do so with caution
review: UPDATE 2/25/2015still using the jungle gym and its pretty much brand new. definitely top notch construction. noticed my original review was unnecessarily long so here's a quick summary of basically everything i mentioned:Short Version:Pros:Device is much better Value than overpriced TRXStudy constructionDual Anchor System is actually better than single anchor IMO, plus you can make it a single with the attachment or bringing the straps closer together so it gives the best of both worlds.Cons:Handle is very stiff and doesn't rotate like TRX.if you use dry erase markers, try rotating the cap around. the handles are basically like that out of the box: tight fitting plastic on plasticthis limits ability to do some exercises to full Range of Motion like reverse flys, bicep curls at least for me (idk maybe i'm using it wrong)Minor Nitpicking: handle has no lateral or side to side play like TRX b/c of foot cradles. TRX has no foot cradles so nylon webbing moves through handle freely from side to side. (see pictures of both if this doesn't make sense)Easy Fix: pop out the handle and  sand down the inner pipe (DON'T OVERSAND or it'll pop out too easily).Bottomline: I would buy it again simply b/c the TRX is so overpriced ($200), but apart from that this device is good on its own merits and its really well built. Plus any minor issues can be fixed very easily (100 grit sand paper or sandinng block)Original Review (aka long version):For the price and compared to the TRX it is a good buy. My only complaint is that I would prefer if they made the handles freely rotate so you can use the device more easily when doing reverse flys, supermans, and other exercises which benefit from a rotating handle. It just feels awkward when you are doing reverse fly exercise and the handle doesn't rotate with you which could encourage you to unnaturally curl your wrist when you reach the end range of that motion. Although to be technically accurate they do rotate as it is just an inner and outer plastic pipe, its just not smooth enough to be functional (think extremely tight fitting plastic on plastic). Smoothly rotating handles would be nice for doing preacher curls or other bicep curling exercises which are really not feasible with the fixed handles on the Lifeline. Granted you can modify the product by popping off the sides of each handle which are part of the foot cradle and perhaps sand/polish it down and use a plastic safe grease like white lithium or silicone. Tried just the grease by itself but you need more clearance between the outer and inner tubes, hence the sanding.The other two things I wish they could have done was to make it possible to adjust the angle of the handles. What I mean by this is that if you look at the typical workout handle such as the TRX, they are just a piece of foam wrapped pvc pipe with nylon webbing running through it so you can move the handle laterally. The lifeline is essentially this but after the handles it is locked into place because the webbing passes out the handle and then makes a 90 deg turn through a narrow channel that is the side of the foot cradle and out a small slit at the end. This added friction from the foot cradle assembly keeps the handle from moving side to side or tilting, rather, 10,15 degrees left and right. While not applicable to all exercises there are certain ones where it would be nice to have some side to side play. However, this may have been an engineering compromise due to the need for stable fixed handles in certain exercises plus the incorporation of the foot cradle.This is for those who are new to suspension training like myself. The new foot cradle is a good feature, but if you are doing ab exercises like mountain climbers you need shoes otherwise the cradle puts uncomfortable stress on your instep or top part of your foot. Lastly if you plan on using this as a strictly door mounted device, i.e. no pullup bar, keep in mind there are certain exercises which you cannot do as effectively such as the mountain climbers since the backwards motion is somewhat blocked by the door preventing full range of motion. Of course if you are a seasoned suspension trainer than you probably already know this.However, I would still recommend the product as it is far less expensive than the TRX and despite the few nit picks here and there it is a very functional device***UPDATE*** I had previously recommended sanding down/lubing the inner tube that slides into the handle. However, after re-examining the handle which I had greased with white lithium I noticed the foot cradle pops out too easily from the handle so the combination of sanding and grease may make it worse as the cradle could potentially pop in and out inadvertently during advanced/high resistance body weight exercises.***UPDATE***11/03/2013 I got rid of the grease and very lightly sanded some of the raised nibs  and the handles rotate very well now. Just don't sand very aggressively. Sand a little, wipe clean and check the fit to make sure it has just enough friction for it to rotate without popping out. If you sand too much (i would advise against using a dremel)you could end up having the sides pop out on certain exercises. Maybe use 150-200 grit to start off and smooth it down with 400 grit. sanding block would be easier than sand paper since it is round so you would have to awkwardly wrap a piece of sandpaper around the male end of the handle and try to shimmy the sandpaper around its cylindrical frame. Its doable but a little frustrating. The only thing I wish for now is if it has more side to side play.  also the instep issue with the foot cradle I mentioned earlier doesn't bother me as much now so it may be a temporary thing once your body acclimates. Anyway on a legal note, these are just my observations.***I am not suggesting or promoting that anyone actually does this to their handles. It just so happens that this particular modification enhances the product's functionality for my own uses. Please  consult the manufacturer as they may have a more appropriate resolution for your particular issue.

prod_name: Lifeline Jungle Gym Suspension Trainer
title: Best TRX tool for home training.
review: I recently hurt myself and had to get these to assist me with getting ready for the gym experience. This is the Best product I have purchased this year for fitness. I know I will see a major difference in 3 months.

prod_name: Lifeline Jungle Gym Suspension Trainer
title: Even better than TRX!
review: I own the TRX suspension trainer, and I love this Lifeline suspension trainer even better! The Lifeline suspension trainer has split anchors, which allows me to position the straps much wider. This wider positioning allows me to do wide-grip inverted rows, which are fantastic for building strength in my back. The TRX suspension trainer only has a single anchor point, which does not allow me to wide-grip inverted rows. Other than that, the TRX straps are just as good as the Lifeline straps. However, I do think the TRX straps are a cooler looking color (bright yellow like the sun) than the Lifeline straps (stop sign red). That's just my opinion.
date: Reviewed in the United States on 7 April 2013

prod_name: Lifeline Jungle Gym Suspension Trainer
title: hard to beat at the price
review: I own this and a TRX.  My biggest complaint with the TRX is how it has about 6 inches of play right to left side . . . while this is done in order to make it easier not to be perfectly  symmetrical when you setup before an exercise, that is not worth the downsides in my mind.  The biggest downside of TRX is switching to single handle.  Is it that hard . . . not really . . . but it seems a waste to do it that way and if you are doing something like consecutive different moves on with tabata timing, it is a huge pain in the rear.The footstrap part of the handle makes MOST foot based moves SO MUCH better.  I say most as lets say you are doing normal planks and then quickly switching to reverse planks, with the TRX you swing a foot over the other and your feet rotate in the handles.  This does not work very well on XT.  This minor downside is not that big of a deal and the upside is HUGE.  Way too many times I waste time with my foot getting into bad spots with the TRX . . . and spending so much effort focusing on the foot and not the actual exercise.This is also much cheaper.It does not feel as well built as TRX.  The part of the handle that rotates does not rotate nearly as well as TRX.  The buckles and strap of the TRX feel better made . . . but in reality nylon straps that are $10 can tow a car.  I have no fear either model would break.I do most all my suspension training with a single anchor as I have mounted one on my basement ceiling.  the connectors for the XT require a big loop to go through, which will be a problem for some anchors.  I do not feel the need to mount a second anchor to do some of the mid or wide stuff with the XT.  To me, one of the biggest upsides of suspension training is the stability needed due to single anchor.  Moving these straps out to shoulder width apart and doing push ups seems less efficient.
date: Reviewed in the United States on 12 December 2023

prod_name: Lifeline Jungle Gym Suspension Trainer
title: Useful for travellers
review: The LifelineUSA XT Jungle Gym is a very high quality product, built of extremely good materials. I bought it primarily for use while travelling, and for this it is very good. The integrated door anchors are sturdy, and rubber coated, so they do not scratch. Two separate "arms" allow for use similar to other suspension trainers (single point of suspension) or wider suspension points, which I find provides better workout flexibility, The integrated foot loops are very easy to use compared to other suspension trainers. They do, however, make it more difficult to pack the product into a suitcase, as they do not fold flat.The "tree branch" extension was something I did not appreciate at first, until I stayed in a hotel during very nice weather and was able to use their park-like back garden to work out - made for a very nice change of environment from the usual hotel room or gym. I suppose this could also be done with some of the other suspension trainers.Overall, I give it an 8 out of 10 in terms of usability, practicality. The only reason it does not get a 10 from me is its relative bulky size compared to something like the TRX trainer, which folds up into a very small bag, but which offers only the single point suspension option. The variety of exercises that can be done using this product are quite wide. The only limitation is the space available in a hotel room - as the only door that is suitable to provide sufficient space is the front door... and this is often in a very cramped space that does not allow you to do many of the exercises. I have often used it in the hotel gym, attaching it to a pull-up bar or even a weight machine support structure.Using it with a hotel room front door does require some care - it's best and most stable when the anchors can be used from the opposite side of the door's opening direction, so your weight is suspended by the entire frame of the door. Using it in the other direction means that there is only the door lock suspending your weight. I recommend using a chair to block up the handle and provide additional support, and extending the "arms" to provide sufficient space for performing the exercises.
date: Reviewed in the United States on 4 September 2023

prod_name: Lifeline Jungle Gym Suspension Trainer
title: A different take on the suspension trainer
review: I bought this as I wanted a suspension trainer and didn't want to spend twice as much for a TRX.  I'd never seen one in the flesh and now that I've had it for a while I can give some thoughts about the differences.I didn't see it at the time, but the loops of this model are solid. For some reason, I through they'd be cloth like the TRX.  They are not.  Now this isn't a bad thing in a lot of ways.  The large loops that you can see are made of a solid plastic, so you can slip your feet into them really easily.  The downside is that I find them quite heavy.  I was intending on travelling with this unit, but frankly, it's too heavy and bulky.I don't have a TRX to physically compare it with, but I can see that a TRX really was designed for travelling.  Lifeline has tried to put in all the extras, that TRX makes you pay for, i.e. both straps have integral large chunks of plastic which you use as stoppers when you slip the handles over the top of a door and close it.  TRX makes you pay for that as an optional extra.  What I see TRX has is a great unit for travelling.  Having it at one unit, with that large strap that you can wrap around just about anything and secure with the carabiner is frankly a better solution for that.  And it's more compact.Does this mean I don't like the XT?  Not at all, it just doesn't suit some types of usage. For the way I currently use it, i.e. at home in my garage, it's perfect. It has all the features of the TRX at half the price.  If I was to travel with it, as the primary motivation, I would have been disappointed, as it would have been too heavy, in my opinion.If you're looking for a quality home suspension trainer, that can do anything a TRX can, at half the price, this definitely suits.  If you're looking for a portable workout solution that packs small and light and can be easily put around just about anything, I would go with the TRX.
date: Reviewed in the United States on 1 February 2014

prod_name: Lifeline Jungle Gym Suspension Trainer
title: Wonderful for exercise
review: Easy to use. Great help for strengthening arms & legs and losing weight
date: Reviewed in the United States on 13 October 2012

prod_name: Lifeline Jungle Gym Suspension Trainer
title: Make sure you can use it properly
review: This is an updated (edited) version of my original reviewMy wife and I had been looking to add suspension training to our workout routine, and after reading reviews of the XT and the TRX, we decided on the XT.  Before buying, we had a major concern about using the product on a door.  In the fitness center in our apartment building, the only available doors open *into* the room (as opposed to closing into the door frame).  We were unsure whether the XT could be used safely on this side of the door (or whether our body weight would pull the door open and we'd fall on our faces).  I went on Lifeline USA's website (the maker of the XT), couldn't find an answer in the FAQs, so sent an email to their "info" address.  Long story short, which is that what I was told by the company (that the XT *can* be used on either side of the door), was in direct contradiction to what's written in the directions that come with the product (which is "never use on the side of the door that opens toward you").  Since I bought the product based on what I was told originally, it was basically a waste of time and effort to buy it, only to find out that I couldn't use it the way I intended.This is new...I contacted the person who made the original "recommendation" and he was very apologetic, and accommodating with returning the product directly to Lifeline so I wouldn't have to incur return shipping (which I would if I returned to Amazon).  My wife and I are disappointed, since we were looking forward to using the XT, but we don't want to risk our safety by attempting to use it in a way that wasn't intended.  It looks like a well made product, so I'll change my original p.o.'ed one star rating to three, because of the help with the return.  For future prospective XT purchasers, just make sure you're going to use it the way it's supposed to be used, which is on the outside of a door, so your weight would pull the door *into* the frame, and not potentially pulling the door open (and causing you to fall).
date: Reviewed in the United States on 23 July 2013

prod_name: Lifeline Jungle Gym Suspension Trainer
title: These are nice, but get the TRX model
review: These have two separate straps. I bought this because the price was low, however, when TRX puts theirs on sale, their pricing is good.  TRX makes a better unit in my opinion & easier to use since theirs is one connection to the door or wall/ceiling mount vs. two separate connections with Jungle Gym.
date: Reviewed in the United States on 27 August 2023

prod_name: Lifeline Jungle Gym Suspension Trainer
title: Generally, a good product but...
review: I can corroborate what other reviewers have already said. I love everything about this product except the red rubberized (silicon?) "grips" that are meant to hold up the slack line. After just two weeks of daily use, both grips softened and stretched and stopped doing their job completely. They just fall down now, leaving big loops of strap that kind of get in the way and make adjusting the strap length between exercises somewhat clunky and frustrating. So, yeah. Three star rating. If you don't think the issue I described will bother you, then consider this a 5-star product and a space-efficient option for a genuinely challenging, strength-building home gym.Do take a walk around your home and assess where you could put it up and have room to workout. In my home, there was no door that met safety specifications and had enough room, so we installed heavy duty ceiling brackets in a spot that was better suited to our needs. That has worked great for us, aside from the grips wearing out.
date: Reviewed in the United States on 6 May 2012

prod_name: BalanceFrom Ab Mat Trainer Abdominal Machine
title: Correcto
review: ### BalanceFrom Ab Mat Trainer ReviewThe BalanceFrom Ab Mat Trainer is a well-designed and effective exercise tool for targeting the abdominal muscles. Here's a comprehensive review of this abdominal machine:#### Design and Build Quality- The Ab Mat Trainer is well-constructed with high-quality materials, providing stability and durability during workouts.- Its ergonomic design ensures proper support for the lower back, making it comfortable to use for extended periods.#### Functionality- This exercise crunch roller effectively isolates and engages the abdominal muscles, allowing for a focused and efficient workout.- The roller motion provides a smooth and controlled movement, reducing strain on the neck and back.#### Ease of Use- The Ab Mat Trainer is easy to set up and can be used by individuals of varying fitness levels.- Its compact size makes it convenient for home use and easy to store when not in use.#### Performance- Users can expect to experience a challenging but rewarding workout with consistent use of this exerciser.- The machine effectively targets the entire core, aiding in the development of strength and definition in the abdominal region.#### ConclusionThe BalanceFrom Ab Mat Trainer is a commendable addition to any home gym, offering an efficient and comfortable means of working the abdominal muscles. Its solid construction, ergonomic design, and overall effectiveness make it a valuable tool for individuals seeking to enhance their core strength and definition.I highly recommend the BalanceFrom Ab Mat Trainer for those looking to step up their abdominal workout routine with a reliable and well-designed exercise crunch roller.

prod_name: BalanceFrom Ab Mat Trainer Abdominal Machine
title: Great lumbar pad...definitely needs to be broken in though
review: I have stage 2 spinal deterioration, so when I do ab excerices that involve laying flat on my back on the floor, I noticed it put some slight strain in my lumbar region.  So I decided that a support pad would be a good way to greater range of motion while taking away the strain.I picked this model as it was one of the cheapest I could find on Amazon (or anywhere for that matter).  While it does give great support, the pad is quite stiff.  For example, when I placed directly in the center of the small of my back, the pad was so rigid that it elevated my entire body off of the floor by about 1/2 inch or so.  This then made doing ab exercises almost impossible, as I'm still developing my ab strength.  So I had to play around with the positioning to find the right comfort level.  After repeated use, the seems to breaking in now, although it is still a bit stiff.This was the only thing preventing me from giving it 5 stars.  That being said, considering the price point, this is still a very well made ab pad.  Not disappointed at all.
date: Reviewed in the United States on 2 August 2021

prod_name: BalanceFrom Ab Mat Trainer Abdominal Machine
title: Meets (and slightly) exceeds my expectations
review: 34yrs/4’10/F/140lbs/beginner level/NO existing back problemsIf crunches/sit-ups are hurting your back this will certainly help that. It’s sole purpose is to provide back support and it does just that. I have no issues with the firmness as that’s the whole reason I bought it. Mind you, I’m only doing at best 100 crunches a day on it. So I cannot attest to how it feels with intensive floor exercise. I will say that’s it’s loads better than the old rolled yoga mat I was using. It doesn’t slid around or out from under me (which was my main issue with just using the yoga mat 😏). No issues with packaging or product presentation. Ordered 12/31/20 and got 1/6/21, not too shabby.In conclusion, it was fairly priced, decent quality, and suits my intended purpose. I would recommend for anyone who’s looking to keep your tailbone and lower back comfortable.

prod_name: Yes4All Ab Exercise Mat with Tailbone Protecting Pad
title: Sturdy and Effective - A Solid Addition to Home Workouts
review: I recently purchased the Yes4All Ab Mat, and after several weeks of regular use, I am confident in awarding it four stars. This piece of equipment has become a key part of my home workout routine, especially for strengthening my core.One of the standout features of this ab mat is its ergonomic design. The mat comfortably supports my lower back, allowing me to focus on my abs without the discomfort that can come from floor exercises. Whether I use the version with tailbone support or without, depending on my day's workout, I appreciate its versatility.The handle is another thoughtful addition. It's not just about the convenience of carrying the mat around, but it also aids in maintaining proper form during exercises. This feature is a big plus for someone keen on perfecting sit-ups and other core exercises.In terms of durability, the Yes4All Ab Mat holds up well. It's made of sturdy materials that have so far shown no signs of wear and tear despite regular use. This durability assures me that it will be a part of my fitness gear for a long time.However, there's room for improvement. While the mat is generally comfortable, I've noticed it can be stiff during longer workout sessions. More cushioning might make it more comfortable for extended use.In conclusion, the Yes4All Ab Mat is a valuable tool for anyone looking to enhance their core workouts at home. Its ergonomic design, sturdy build, and helpful handle make it a practical and effective choice. I'm happy to give it a solid four stars and recommend it to others seeking to strengthen their core muscles.
date: Reviewed in the United States on 5 January 2024

prod_name: Yes4All Ab Exercise Mat with Tailbone Protecting Pad
title: Wow, exactly what I wanted!
review: Well, I took a chance on this based on some reviews and the reasonable price. I bought one of those bars that you attach to the bottom of the door to hold your feet while doing situps. Situps have begun to hurt my tailbone if I'm just on bare floor or carpet, so I ordered this to try to address that. I wasn't expecting too much. Wow, it's perfect enough that it motivated me to write a review. First, it folds in half, making it easier to stick somewhere out of the way when you're not using it. Second, I couldn't really feel ANY pressure on my tailbone. And I'm a bigger guy. Much more support than a rubber foldup yoga mat. All I had to think about was executing the moves, not trying to avoid hurting my tailbone. Also...as a side benefit, I know fitness gurus have moved away from "situps" and more toward "crunches." The "hump" on this pad fits to the small of one's back and encourages you to stay maybe a hand's width off the floor, but you can lie down on it if you wanted your shoulders to touch the floor. Anyway, as I DID that, my lower back cracked (in a fantastic way--like a satisfying stretch). I sit at a desk, and this was a great feel for my lower back, which is not the easiest thing to crack or stretch.
date: Reviewed in the United States on 5 January 2023

My back felt like just my spine on a hard floor. The first time I used this the only pain that crossed my mind was the good kind of muscles working. My back didn’t even cross my mind. Like some reviews said, it is kind of narrow so I don’t know how a man with a broad back would like it but for me (5’3, 130 lb. Pretty average build for height) it’s perfect. It doesn’t take up any room to store, just fold it and prop it against the wall. I recommend it.

prod_name: Yes4All-1-inch-Weight-Plates-Dumbbells
title: Great Cheap Telescope Mount Counterweights
review: I bought these as a cheap counterweight for an iOptron CEM60. I bought an inexepensive carbide hole saw and chucked in a cheap Wen drill press (all from Amazon). Cast iron is easy to work, but very messy swarf gets everywhere.I've tried other brands of cheap weights, but these are close to having parallel faces so that they fit together with no gaps.Highly recommended as counterweights, probably OK too for bar weights.
date: Reviewed in the United States on 12 December 2023

prod_name: Yes4All-1-inch-Weight-Plates-Dumbbells
title: Fine, But May Need to Expand Holes
review: I got these weights to use with a set of Yes4All dumbbells (PN ‎DL2Z) I purchased about 4 months prior. I needed just a bit more weight than the 52 lbs that came with the dumbbell sets for some exercises. Since these were advertised as 1" weights, and so (I thought) were the ones that came with the dumbbell sets, and since they are from the same company, I assumed they would fit on the dumbbell bars just fine. As you've likely guessed by now, they did not. I had to ream out approximately 1-2mm of material from the holes in these plates for them to fit on the bars. For other "standard" 1" bars, this may not be an issue, but it's definitely the case for the Yes4All dumbbell bars.Ultimately, it was a minor inconvenience for me. It took about 30 min per weight with a Dremel and carbide bit to ream out the holes so that they would fit. However many people probably don't have those kinds of tools at their disposal, so figured I'd give a heads-up.Other than that issue, the weights are just fine, and were the least expensive I could find on Amazon.
date: Reviewed in the United States on 8 January 2024

prod_name: Yes4All-1-inch-Weight-Plates-Dumbbells
title: Great product, even better customer service.
review: I've been slowly building a mini home gym for those days I can't make it to my gym.  I've ordered a few of the Yes4All weight plates, these are perfect for the 1 inch adjustable dumbbells and 1 inch EZ curl bar.  They are true to the weight advertised, and are durable.  I recently ordered 2 combos of 4 plates, but my order was incomplete upon delivery, and I was missing 2 plates.  I contacted Yes4All customer service to explain my situation, and provided my invoice number, and a photo of the items I actually received.  The Yes4All customer service team is top notch.  I contacted them via email on a Friday afternoon, and by Sunday morning, they shipped me 2 replacement plates to finally complete my order.  I thank Yes4All for the amazing customer service, and outstanding product.  It great to know that there are still companies out there that value their customers.  I highly recommend this company, and their products if your looking to invest in some home gym equipment.
date: Reviewed in the United States on 25 October 2023

prod_name: Portzon 8 Colors Options Compatible with Set of 2 Rubber Dumbbell
title: Well Made & Comfortable Set of Dumbbells
review: I purchased the Portzon Set of 2x 4 lbs Neoprene Dumbbells in blue to replace a pair I lent to my niece at the beginning of the pandemic. At this point, I decided to just buy these for me to use so she could keep the others.I primarily use these after my warmup, throwing punches, light swings & flys, to get my shoulders & back ready for strength training.The dumbbells arrived on time & w/out issue. There were no noticeable defects or damage to the neoprene coating. The coating does have a comfortable nonslip texture. The quality seems to be right on par w/the other varies manufactured lightweight neoprene coated dumbbells I own. These would be fine for all sizes of hands. If you have smaller hands, you will be able to grip & hold on to the dumbbells securely & comfortably.Thank you for taking the time to read my review, I hope you found it helpful.
date: Reviewed in the United States on 2 January 2021

review: These handheld exercise weights are made of good materials, easy to hold, and come in cool colors.I got the one-pound weight based on the advice of my instructor, because I am a senior and just starting with weight exercises.  One pound feels too light, making me wonder if I should have gotten at least a 3 pounder.  Time will tell.  I will likely be ordering heavier weights in the near future.highly recommend this product
date: Reviewed in the United States on 16 December 2021

prod_name: Portzon 8 Colors Options Compatible with Set of 2 Rubber Dumbbell
title: TINY! PERFECT FOR WALKING+JOGGING
review: I originally looked into buying those expensive 1 lb wrist cuffs, but no way was I going to spend $55 for a set of those. These weights are only about $5 each.  I was surprised at how small these one pound weights are, but in a very good way.  They are the perfect size to hold one in each hand and still hang onto your keys, while walking or jogging. Plus if you need to throw something at an advancing Coyote or Raccoon; to stave off an attack while out there in the park, then these fit the bill.  You don't have to hope to find a rock,  because your carrying these in your hands already.Just enough weight to do some arm toning and not get pained muscles from carrying too much weight.  Tiny + Cute + Useful!
date: Reviewed in the United States on 26 June 2021

prod_name: Portzon 8 Colors Options Compatible with Set of 2 Rubber Dumbbell
title: GOOD LIGHTWEIGHT DUMBBELLS FOR A NICE LIGHTWEIGHT PRICE
review: Five-pound dumbbells are a good, light, appropriate weight for helping to heal an injury. (Me: baseball player with torn rotator cuff injured while not playing baseball.) You don't have to be an athlete like me to benefit from using simple dumbbells like these as part of your injury healing regimen. Just "listen" to your injury, increasing the intensity and range of motion in your workouts slowly and gently.IMHO these dumbbells are a nice choice. They're well-made, inexpensive, color-coded, and clearly marked with their weights.
date: Reviewed in the United States on 16 November 2022

title: Solid weights!

We love the different bright color by the weight size.Only thing I disliked was the box was very flimsy (broken open and held on by a wrap around elastic band) and the delivery.

prod_name: Portzon 8 Colors Options Compatible with Set of 2 Rubber Dumbbell
title: Nice Solid Dumbbells For Great Big Man Hands!
review: Finally, a set of 5 lb. barbells that have a long 4 inch grip. I previously ordered two other sets - one from Amazon and another from WalMart; both of those orders had to be returned because the grips were just too small to fit my man hands. Those other brands were obviously designed for tiny girl or gnome hands, not great big man hands like mine. And, yes the color is lovely. I will probably wrap the grips with some sort of fabric to prevent the hand surface from becoming dirty. With a little gorilla tape to hold a protective covering tight on the handles, I am satisfied that I will enjoy these weights for many years to come.
date: Reviewed in the United States on 22 June 2022
